Extract and read EPUB e-books

Source: R/epubr.R
epub.Rd

Read EPUB format e-books into a data frame using epub or extract epub archive files for direct use with epub_unzip.

epub(file, fields = NULL, drop_sections = NULL, chapter_pattern = NULL,
  ...)

epub_unzip(file, exdir = tempdir())

Arguments

file

character, input EPUB filename. May be a vector for epub. Always a single file for epub_unzip.
fields

character, vector of metadata fields (data frame columns) to parse from metadata, if they exist. See details.
drop_sections

character, a regular expression pattern string to identify text sections (rows of nested text data frame) to drop.
chapter_pattern

character, a regular expression pattern string to attempt distinguishing nested data frame rows of chapter text entries from other types of entries.
...

additional arguments. Currently unsupported.
exdir

character, extraction directory to place archive contents (files).

Value

epub returns a data frame. epub_unzip returns nothing but extracts files from an epub file archive.

Details

The primary function here is epub. It parses EPUB file metadata and textual content into a data frame. The output data frame has one row for each file in file. It has metadata in all columns except the data column, which is a column of nested data frames containing e-book text by book section (e.g., chapters). Both the primary and nested data frames are tibbles and safe to print to the console "as is".

Be careful if file is a long vector of many EPUB files. This could take a long time to process as well as could potentially use up all of your system RAM if you have far too many large books in one call to epub.

The fields argument can be used to limit the columns returned. E.g., fields = c("title", "creator", "date", "identifier", "publisher", "file"). Some fields will be returned even if not in fields. You should already know what metadata fields are in the EPUB file. file in fields will include the original file name, in case this is different from the content of a source field that may be present in the metadata.

The chapter_pattern argument may be helpful for bulk processing of similarly formatted EPUB files. This should be ignored for poorly formatted EPUB files or where there is inconsistent naming across an e-book collection. Like with fields, you should explore file metadata in advance or this argument will not be useful. If provided, a column nchap is added to the output data frame giving the guessed number of chapters. The section column will also be updated to reflect guessed chapters with new, consistent chapter IDs.

If using epub_unzip directly on individual EPUB files, this gives you control over where to extract archive files to and what to do with them subsequently. epub uses epub_unzip internally to extract EPUB archive files to the R session temp directory (with tempdir()).

Examples

file <- system.file("dracula.epub", package = "epubr")
epub_unzip(file) # unzip to directly inspect archive files
list.files(file.path(tempdir(), "OEBPS"))
#>  [1] "@public@vhost@g@gutenberg@html@files@345@345-h@345-h-0.htm.html"   
#>  [2] "@public@vhost@g@gutenberg@html@files@345@345-h@345-h-1.htm.html"   
#>  [3] "@public@vhost@g@gutenberg@html@files@345@345-h@345-h-10.htm.html"  
#>  [4] "@public@vhost@g@gutenberg@html@files@345@345-h@345-h-11.htm.html"  
#>  [5] "@public@vhost@g@gutenberg@html@files@345@345-h@345-h-12.htm.html"  
#>  [6] "@public@vhost@g@gutenberg@html@files@345@345-h@345-h-13.htm.html"

x <- epub(file)
x
#> # A tibble: 1 x 9
#>   rights   identifier    creator  title language subject date  source    data  
#>   <chr>    <chr>         <chr>    <chr> <chr>    <chr>   <chr> <chr>     <list>
#> 1 Public ~ http://www.g~ Bram St~ Drac~ en       Horror~ 1995~ http://w~ <tibb~

x <- epub(file, fields = c("title", "creator"), drop_sections = "^cov")
x
#> # A tibble: 1 x 3
